Title: Comparison of Outcomes of Antibiotic Drugs and Appendectomy: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Background: While antibiotics have been validated as an effective alternative to appendectomy in adults with appendicitis, the generalisability of trial results to broader patient populations remains uncertain. This study compares outcomes between participants in the CODA randomised controlled trial (RCT) and a parallel cohort study of participants who self-selected treatment.

Methods: The CODA trial was a multicenter RCT conducted across 25 US medical centers, enrolling participants from May 3, 2016, to February 5, 2020. Eligible adults with appendicitis were randomised to receive either appendectomy or antibiotics. A parallel cohort included patients who declined randomisation and self-selected treatment. The primary outcome was the rate of appendectomy within 30 days, with all participants followed for at least one year. Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed. Blinding was not applicable.

Participants: A total of 1094 participants were randomised (appendectomy: 547, antibiotics: 547), and 510 were in the self-selection cohort (appendectomy: 253, antibiotics: 257). The study included adults with appendicitis, with a mean age of 38.2 years in the randomised group and 35.8 years in the self-selection cohort.

Results: The rate of appendectomy by 30 days was 15.3% in the self-selection antibiotics group and 19.2% in the randomised antibiotics group (difference, 3.9%; 95% CI, âˆ’1.7% to 9.5%). No significant differences in adverse events were reported between groups.

Interpretation: The outcomes were substantially similar between the randomised and self-selection cohorts, suggesting the generalisability of the RCT results to the broader community. Trial Registration: ClinicalTrials.gov Identifier: NCT02800785. Funding: Not specified.
